ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HIGHER MALAY
(Assessment of performance of Malay language students)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Ahmad Mohd Magad -

    1. To ask the Minister for Education whether his Ministry's assessment of the performance of Malay language students in schools will allow more students to take Higher Malay.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Question No. 1, Sir.

    The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry has relaxed the criteria for allowing pupils to take Higher Mother Tongue. From year 2000, EM2 pupils who have scored a Band 1 in their mother tongue language, (Malay Language (ML), Chinese Language (CL) or Tamil Language (TL)) and at least a Band 2 in English Language and Mathematics, at the Primary 4 Streaming examination, will be given the opportunity to offer a Higher Mother Tongue Language at Primary 5.

    Currently, pupils who are in the top 10% of the PSLE cohort are allowed to offer Higher Mother Tongue (ML, CL and TL) at Secondary One. In addition, those who are in the top 11% to 20% of the cohort and who have scored an A* in the mother tongue language and an A in English Language are also allowed to offer Higher Mother Tongue at Secondary One. This applies to the Malay Language, Chinese Language and Tamil Language. In total, about 350 pupils in Secondary 1 are eligible to offer Higher Malay Language in 1999.

    We have now broadened this to include pupils in the top 21% to 30% of the cohort, subject to the same language requirements as for pupils in the top 11% to 20% group. This will allow 150 more Secondary 1 pupils to offer Higher Malay in our schools.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin (Nominated Member): Sir, I would like to ask the

Column: 8

Minister, compared to other subjects, for example, Mathematics, Science and English, are Malay students facing problems in learning the Malay language?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: The Malay students in our schools have done progressively better over the years. But there is still room for improvement. Our Malay students can get more out of our education system than they are getting today. But their performance in the Malay language is not the factor that hampers their progression through our education system. In fact, it is the other subjects, English, Mathematics and Science, for example, which hamper their progression through our education system.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin: Can I ask the Minister whether, that being the case, a CL `B' equivalent in this case may not be necessary for Malay students and, secondly, if Mathematics, Science and English are some of the weaker subjects faced by Malay students, would the Minister consider introducing special programmes and syllabus to enable Malay students to cope with these subjects?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Whether or not ML `B' is required is a matter of continuing discussion which we are having. We have made no decision on that yet. Whether or not we want to have special programmes for Mathematics and Science and a special syllabus, perhaps a Mathematics `B' or Science `B'? We already have at the secondary school level Mathematics and Science at various levels. For example, we have Additional Mathematics and Mathematics D. We have the pure sciences, Physics, Chemistry and Biology, and we have the combined sciences, Physics with Chemistry, Physics with Biology, etc. So students can take a combination of subjects which suits their aptitudes and which they think they can do well in and which would be most appropriate considering what further education they want to go on to.

    For Mathematics and Science, it would not be beneficial to have a separate syllabus, particularly if it is tailored for Malay students, because it would not serve the purpose of providing a solid

Column: 9

foundation that is necessary for progression, particularly in technical and science courses, in further education. But, say, in English, for example, for the EM1 and EM2 students, although we do not have a different standard, we do have a programme which is beginning to show quite good success at the lower primary level, Primary 1 and Primary 2, and it is called the learning support programme. This programme provides support through learning support coordinators to children who have difficulties in English and it provides them additional teaching and coaching in English so that they increase their reading age in English and that will help them in all their other subjects.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Cheng San): Sir, would the Ministry consider identifying more schools to offer Higher Malay now that the eligibility has been extended to pupils in the top 21%-30% cohort?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Sir, there are now currently 10 schools which are offering Higher Malay and four of them function as Higher Malay Centres to which students who are studying in schools close by come to as well. Our assessment is that the geographical spread and the number of schools are adequate, but if there is a need we will be prepared to increase the number of centres.

    Mr Hawazi Daipi (Sembawang): Sir, does the Ministry have any other plans to help create the Malay cultural elite through schools?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: When we were discussing the Chinese Language review the Ministry has indicated that it would be prepared to consider a language elective programme in Malay at the junior college level if there is a demand for this. We have to study this. Some of the other measures which we were talking about include the bonus points for entry to courses in the university where Higher Mother Tongue would be useful, for example, in communications studies. These things would apply to all the mother tongue languages, whether it is Chinese, Malay or Tamil. This is still in discussion with the universities.

Column: 10

SPECIAL ASSISTANCE PLAN SCHOOL IN NORTHERN PART OF
SINGAPORE


    2. Encik Harun A Ghani asked the Minister for Education whether his Ministry will build a Special Assistance Plan (SAP) school in the northern part of Singapore.

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry has recently announced the establishment of a 10th SAP school, Nan Hua Secondary School, in the west zone. This, and the existing

9    SAP schools, have sufficient capacity and geographical spread to meet the needs of students who qualify for and wish to study in SAP schools.

    While there is currently no SAP school in the north zone, students living in the north can choose schools which are accessible by public transport, like Catholic High School and CHIJ St. Nicholas.

    Encik Harun A Ghani (Hong Kah): Sir, why was Nan Hua Secondary School chosen and not some other schools in the northern part?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: We did a study of the pattern of students who may be eligible to take Higher Chinese and we looked at where the current SAP schools are, and we decided that Nan Hua was the school which was in the correct geographical location to cater for these students as well as having the appropriate history, characteristics and community support which would help to make it successful as a SAP school.

    Encik Harun A Ghani: Sir, how many non-Chinese students are there in that school and were they given a place in the school which they wanted to go?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Nan Hua currently has 134 non-Chinese students studying in the school across all levels. This is about 10% of the entire population of the school. The existing students will not be disadvantaged in any way and the current arrangement for instruction in the other mother tongue languages will continue.

Column: 11

SCHEME B BUS OPERATORS

(Amalgamation into a limited company)


    3. Mr Shriniwas Rai asked the Minister for Communications if he will consider amalgamating into a limited company Scheme B bus operators so as to serve the public better.

    The Minister of State for Communications (Dr John Chen Seow Phun) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Scheme B bus operators are mainly individual operators whose main business is to provide chartering and school bus services. They also serve some of the scheduled bus routes during peak hours to supplement the two major bus operators, SBS and TIBS. My Ministry does not see the need for them to amalgamate in order to improve their services. Nevertheless, there is nothing to prevent them to amalgamate on their own if they find it advantageous to do so.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Sir, would the Minister consider, like the taxi drivers who were individual operators and the system has benefited because of amalgamation, that it would be a good idea to encourage these Scheme B bus operators to form a company even if they are not coming on their own?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, at the moment, there are already two bus companies, SBS and TIBS. They cover the whole of Singapore quite adequately. These Scheme B buses are to supplement their services for some routes where there is demand. It is a different situation compared to the taxi industry in the earlier days where you had individual taxi drivers and in order to organise the industry there was a need then to help them to come together to form a cooperative. But here it is a different situation and there is really no need for us to do that because they are the niche service, so to speak.

Column: 11

APARTMENTS IN NASSIM JADE AND SCOTTS 28

(Report of purchases by Senior Minister and Deputy Prime
Minister)


    4. Mr J B Jeyaretnam asked the Prime Minister whether he will make available to

Column: 12

the House the report of the Minister for Finance on the purchases by the Senior Minister and by the Deputy Prime Minister BG Lee Hsien Loong of apartments in Nassim Jade and Scotts 28.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I would like to reply on behalf of the Prime Minister.

    The NCMP has asked the Prime Minister to make available to the House my report to the Prime Minister on the purchases by the Senior Minister and Deputy Prime Minister BG Lee Hsien Loong of properties in Nassim Jade and Scotts 28.

    Firstly, I would like to clarify that there is no single report as such. On 21st March 1996, the Prime Minister instructed me to investigate market talk suggesting that improprieties may have been involved in the purchases and that HPL may have violated SES rules in the transactions. I instructed Mr Koh Beng Seng of MAS to conduct the investigations. He reported to me his conclusion that no improprieties were involved in the purchases and that HPL had not contravened SES rules, and I informed the Prime Minister accordingly.

    Furthermore, this House had an extensive debate on the circumstances surrounding the Senior Minister and DPM Lee's purchases of the HPL properties over three days on 21st, 22nd and 23rd May 1996. At these sittings, both the Prime Minister and I gave statements to the House on the investigations carried out and our conclusions. Senior Minister and DPM Lee also made statements explaining their purchases.

    May I suggest that the NCMP carefully reads his Hansard.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): The Minister says there was no single report. Are we to understand that there were a series of reports made to the Prime Minister or are we to understand that the purchases were simply discussed at informal meetings between him and the Prime Minister?

Column: 13



    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: As I mentioned in my reply earlier, the reports were made to me by Mr Koh Beng Seng and there were several reports. The Prime Minister was informed accordingly. No evidence was found of any improprieties and that was quite evident from the debates which had taken place. May I suggest to the NCMP that he no longer waste this House's time in raising this issue which is for his political agenda.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I am grateful to the Hon. Minister for his suggestion but I think he should leave it to the Party and to me to make our own judgment.

    I have read the statement of the Prime Minister at this debate. May I ask - I do not know whether the Minister for Finance can answer this - why was the suggestion of the Senior Minister for a Commission of Inquiry not followed up?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: There was no evidence whatsoever from Mr Koh Beng Seng's report to justify any such action. It would be a waste of time. Are you suggesting that Mr Koh is incompetent in his investigations?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I tell the Minister that he should not be asking me questions. I am here to ask the questions. Would the Minister agree that Parliament is not a forum for an inquiry and that if the public had to be satisfied, a Commission of Inquiry would have been the proper forum?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: If Parliament is not the proper forum, I do not know what is, especially in the circumstances where there is no prima facie evidence of any improprieties.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I think the Minister for Finance has made a very stinging statement about the Opposition. It does not mean that whenever the Opposition asks awkward questions, it is done for a political reason. We are here to ask questions and the Minister should thank the Opposition Members for asking awkward questions so that all these issues can be cleared up.

Column: 14



    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Chiam, what is your supplementary question on this subject?

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, I think it is unfair of the Minister to make that statement.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: May I respond to Mr Chiam? I was not in any way referring to him or his Party. I was referring specifically to one individual.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: And to the Workers' Party. May I ask the Minister whether he will agree that greater transparency which the Government proclaims is the desired object or necessary for good government would have been achieved by a full Commission of Inquiry with the public hearing the whole evidence that is laid before the Commission and deciding for themselves?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I fully agree on the need for transparency but three days of debate in Parliament should be more than adequate.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister agree that satisfaction by the Prime Minister, albeit by the Prime Minister, is not the same as satisfaction of the public?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: It has nothing to do with the satisfaction of the Prime Minister. I say it again that there is no prima facie evidence of anything that has gone wrong. So why are you pursuing the subject, especially when your Party Member has had the opportunity during the debate to raise these same questions?

    Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, can you proceed with your next question?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: As you please, Sir. Question No. 5.

MR HO JUAN THAI

(Non-issue of passport)


    5. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs what are the reasons for the reluctance of the Immigration authorities to issue Mr Ho Juan Thai a passport.

Column: 15



    The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Jeyaretnam is fully aware of the reasons why Singapore Immigration and Registration (SIR) has not issued Mr Ho Juan Thai a passport. Mr Jeyaretnam had been closely associated with Mr Ho, a member of the Workers' Party, and had acted as Mr Ho's counsel previously.

    SIR has not issued Mr Ho a Singapore passport for the following reasons:

    a) Mr Ho is required to respond to SIR's queries over the renewal endorsement in his expired Singapore passport. Mr Ho had publicly declared that he amended the expiry date of his passport, which expired in December 1976, to enter the UK in July 1977. If this is true, this may constitute an offence of forgery.

    b) Mr Ho has been an Exit Permit defaulter since August 1986. He is therefore required to answer for his Exit Permit offence upon his return to Singapore.

    c) Although no warrant of arrest has been issued against Mr Ho, the authorities would like to interview him over his racially inflammatory speeches at election rallies during the December 1976 General Election in which he ran as the Workers' Party election candidate in Bukit Panjang.

    Mr Jeyaretnam, acting as counsel for Mr Ho, was informed in 1986 why Mr Ho could not be issued a passport. Mr Ho himself was informed of the reasons in writing by the Singapore High Commissioner in London and MINDEF in 1992, when he applied for a new Singapore passport. The High Commissioner has also told Mr Ho that SIR is ready to issue him with a one-way Document of Identity to facilitate his return to Singapore if he so wishes.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister identify the provision of law under which a citizen of Singapore can be denied a passport?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, I think Mr Jeyaretnam very well knows the

Column: 16

answer. It is found in the Passports Act, read with the Passport Regulations (Regulation 5).

    Mr Jeyaretnam: If Mr Ho has committed any offence, the answer is to prosecute him and ask for extradition of him from the United Kingdom to Singapore. I take it there is an extradition treaty. Why deny him a passport?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: That is exactly what we want to find out and have asked him to return. We are prepared to issue him a Document of Identity for him to return to Singapore, after which the authorities would question him to ascertain whether or not he has committed any offence and, if so, what offences he has committed. So, Mr Ho should come back and we can get to the bottom of it.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): The Minister of State also says that the agency would like to interview or question him. I would like to know whether or not the Government still considers Mr Ho Juan Thai a threat to the internal security of Singapore.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: That is the very reason why we want to interview him. He has to come back, he would be interviewed, and then we would decide.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister, following the Member's question, what is the threat that Mr Ho poses? Is it the same threat that the Worker's Party poses to the People's Action Party?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: I have outlined the circumstances why the authorities want to question Mr Ho. There are three instances and they are all in the answer.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister whether he really thinks that he has answered the question?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: The answer is obvious.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, if you have no more questions, could you proceed with your next question?

Column: 17



    Mr Jeyaretnam: Yes, all right, because we are not getting the answers, Sir, Question No. 6.

MR ABDUL RAZAK B AHMAD

(Denial of entry into Singapore)


    6. Mr J B Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether there are any good reasons for denying Mr Abdul Razak b Ahmad entry into Singapore.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Abdul Razak Ahmad, a Malaysian, was expelled and banned from entering Singapore with effect from 18th November 1966, because he took part in subversive activities while studying at the Law Faculty of Singapore University.

    Entry into any country is a privilege and not a right granted to foreigners. It is the view of this Government that Abdul Razak is an undesirable person who should not be granted the privilege of entering Singapore.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister say why this Order was made against him? Was it not because he was part of a group asking for greater academic freedom in the universities in those days?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: As I have said in my answer, he has engaged in subversive activities. Abdul Razak was actively involved in the Nanyang University students' agitation for the restoration of the Nanyang University Students' Union and also in Ngee Ann College's agitation in 1966 for the college to be made a full-fledged university. This resulted in several processions, demonstrations and indeed a violent clash between students and the riot Police.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister of State say whether a demand for greater academic freedom in the universities is considered by the Government to be a threat to the security of Singapore?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, it was not just a matter of debate about more freedom. As I have said in my answer,

Column: 18

there were demonstrations, processions and fights. So it is a different thing altogether.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: What is wrong with them in maintaining their protests by way of demonstrations, if it was necessary?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, Mr Jeyaretnam is in this House, using our time to espouse the cause of a foreigner who, in 1966, participated in certain acts which were a destabilising factor in Singapore, and after that he also had in several ways made several unfriendly remarks. And indeed in 1986, he instigated and led a protest against Singapore over the then Israeli President Chaim Herzog's visit.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai: May I ask the Minister whether Abdul Razak applied to the Government to review the Order? Has he himself applied? The second question is whether the Government would consider, in view of the changed circumstances, allowing him entry on conditions?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: After the ban was made in 1966, in fact, he was allowed in Singapore on four occasions for various reasons. He did apply to ask for the ban to be lifted, but the Government in 1984 turned it down.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai: Would the Minister consider, in view of the changed circumstances, whether it is still a risk to let him come in?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: He has not applied. If he applies, we can consider it. But in terms of what he has done in 1966, the reason for the ban is fully justifiable.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister explain why another student, Mr Chan Kian Hui who was also sent out of Singapore, had that Order revoked after a month's time, when Mr Razak has been prevented from coming in all these years?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: If Mr Jeyaretnam files a question, I will give a reply.

Column: 19



    Mr Chiam See Tong: It was mentioned that Abdul Razak was arrested for agitating the conversion of Ngee Ann College to a full-fledged university. May I ask what is wrong with that? Does it affect the security of a country?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: As I have mentioned, it is not just about making a point for raising the status of the College, but what he did was he was involved in certain agitations which resulted in processions, demonstrations, fights and riots. And he is a foreigner too.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister whether he was prosecuted for these riots and fights? Why was he not prosecuted?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: One wonders why Mr Jeyaretnam is spending so much time of the House espousing his cause. Is there some interest?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I remind the Minister that it is not for him to ask me questions. We know that banishment or prohibition orders against several other people have all been revoked or taken back. Why is this man in particular?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, surely the circumstances must be different. Just because some orders have been revoked does not mean that we must do it for this man.

WATER-WORKS IN JOHORE

(Employment of Singaporeans and Malaysians)

    This Bill seeks to amend the Infectious Diseases Act (Chapter 137 of the 1985 Revised Edition) and the Infectious Diseases (Amendment) Act 1992, to strengthen the public health control of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Singapore.

    The Infectious Diseases Act was passed in 1976 to prevent the introduction and spread of all infectious diseases in Singapore. AIDS, which is caused by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV), became a notifiable disease under the Infectious Diseases Act in 1985. In 1992, the Act was amended to include provisions to tighten the control of AIDS and to provide for the confidentiality of infected persons. However, changing trends of HIV infection in recent years require us to make further amendments to the Act in order to strengthen the public health control of AIDS in Singapore. HIV/AIDS situation in Singapore

    The number of HIV infected Singaporeans has been increasing over the years since 1985 when the first case was reported. Between 1985 and 1990, a total of 61 cases were reported. The rate of increase has accelerated since then. In 1991 alone, 42 new cases of HIV/AIDS were reported, as against the total of 61 cases between 1985-1990. Over the last four years, the number of cases shot up to more than 100 per year. Last year, 1998, the number climbed to nearly 200. The exact number was 199. In total, there were 930 Singapore residents notified to be HIV infected between 1985 and 1998, of whom 423 had asymptomatic infection, 196 had full blown AIDS and 311 had passed away. In addition, a total of 2,813 foreigners had been tested to be HIV positive while they were in Singapore. About 80% of such foreigners were work permit holders and applicants. They have already left Singapore.

    The pattern of transmission of the HIV infection has changed over the years, from a predominantly homosexual infection to one that is mostly spread by

heterosexual transmission. Over the last three years, heterosexual transmission accounted for an average of 78% of all new cases. Most of these cases had unprotected sex with prostitutes and casual acquaintances in Singapore or abroad.

    The pattern of heterosexual infection itself has also changed. The proportion of married men among new cases of HIV infection among male Singaporeans has increased from 10% in 1991 to 30% in 1998.

    With this shift of the infection to the married population, infected men are bringing the infection home to their wives. A further tragic consequence is that there are more reports recently of children with HIV infection. The first HIV infected child was reported in 1991. Since then, eight more cases have been reported between 1997 and l998. All of them have been infected perinatally. Families have been devastated by the HIV infection. We have had at least two families where all members were infected. This emerging trend needs to be addressed.

    Another major concern that has arisen recently is HIV transmission through blood transfusion. In 1997, my Ministry reported the first case of HIV transmission through blood transfusion. Two persons became infected after they received blood from a donor who was in the window period of the HIV infection. This is despite the stringent measures taken by the Singapore Blood Transfusion Services (SBTS) to exclude donors with risk factors because the donor had lied in this case. The HIV infected donor admitted to a total of six offences under section 182 of the Penal Code. He was charged in court early last year and given a sentence of 12 months. Timely actions need to be taken to prevent further spread of the disease within the population.     Sir, I will now deal with the main provisions of the Bill.

    Currently, a person who furnishes false information at the Blood Bank is charged under section 182 of the Penal Code. This carries a maximum penalty of $1,000 and/or a maximum jail sentence of six months.

    The identity of the person with AIDS/HIV infection is protected under section 20D of the existing Act, where disclosure of identity and HIV status is allowed only to specified categories of persons. To address the public health issues that have arisen over recent years which I have described just now, my Ministry proposes that new exceptions to medical confidentiality be included. The main objective of such new exceptions is to prevent transmission of the infection through irresponsible behaviour by persons who are infected and to allow those who have been exposed to the risk of the infection to be informed early, counselled and tested.
